CHAPTER.P: The HttpClient package implements the HTTP 0.9 and HTTP 1.0 protocols, conform RFC 1945, providing a flexible programming interface. Its interface is related with the retrieving of the documents over the network, as well as with accessing their transmission rate.
The HttpClient package was written in Oz 3 and compiled with Mozart Compiler 1.1.0 (19991213) and (20000111).

The HttpClient package consists of the following modules:
HttpClient: is the main programming interface of the HttpClient package. It deals with the parse of the input and output parameters, initiate of HTTP 0.9 and HTTP 1.0 compliant communications and transmission rate control. The HttpClient module is described in .
HttpReqRep: deals with the HTTP reqests and responses.
HttpHeader: stores the HTTP header formats as well as input and output default parameters.
ListUtils: consists of some useful List processing tools.
OpenConnection: deals with socket connections and files, as well as with transmission rate computation. This module can be used apart of this package in order to implement other transmission protocols (i.e. FTP).

The HttpClient module is the main programming interface of the HttpClient package. It deals with the input and output parameters parsing, HTTP 0.9 and HTTP 1.0 compliant communications initialisation and transmission rate control. In the followings we enumerate and describe the classes this module consists of.

Service is the base class for all the other classes present in this module. Hence, all the other classes (CgiGET, CgiPOST, CgiISINDEX, UrlGET and UrlHEAD) will inherit its public and protected methods. The programmer is advised to use them instead of Service.

SECTION.P: The exceptions raised by the methods of the classes present in HttpClient package are atoms.

SUBSECTION.P:
These exceptions are raised by all vulnerable methods. They are as follows:
conPremClosed : the socket connection was closed by the peer while still reading it.
errCloseCon : there was a problem when closing the connection.
errCloseFile : there was a problem when closing the file.
errReadSocket : there was a problem when reading the socket.
errRemFile : there was a problem when removing the file.
errOpenCon : there was a problem while trying to open the connection.
errOpenFile : there was a problem while trying to open the file.
errWriteFile : there was a problem when writing the file.
errWriteSocket : there was a problem when writing the socket.

These exceptions are raised by the vulnerable methods involved in CGI parameters and URL strings parsing. They are as follows:
errCgiPrms : there is a problem with the CGI parameters.
errLargeCgiPrms : the length of the CGI parameters is to large.
errUrlChrs : the URL contains special chars.

SECTION.P: In this section we describe the parameters found in most of the methods presented within this chapter.

ITEM.P.SILENT: The InPrms record provides the programmer with a flexible interface. If not bound nor present, its features willbe given default values.
ITEM.P: FileName is a string containing the path of the file the document will be put in. The file is written while the document is beeing transfered.
RTime is an integer specifing the instanteous transmission rate checking periodicity.
Smpl is an integer specifing the number of the last instantaneously rates to be considered when computing the transmission rate (i.e. when method fetchRate is invoked, see ).
ToFile is a boolean specifing if the document should be saved into a file or not.
ToStrm is a boolean specifing if the document should be returned as a byte stream or not.

SUBSECTION.P: Url is a string specifing the URL location of the document to be retrieved (e.g. "http://www.info.ucl.ac.be" of "www.yahoo.com").

ITEM.P.SILENT: HttpPrms record contains the HTTP 1.0 compliant headers. Each of its feature coresponds to a header and will be bound if it is provided by the peer, before the document is fetched. All parameters are strings.
ITEM.P: Server represents the name of the peer.
Date represents the date and time the document was built by the peer. Its semantics is described in RFC 822.
Last_Modified represents the date and time the document was last modified. Its semantics is described in RFC 822.
Location represents the URL where the requested document was temporarely or permanentely moved. When it is bound, the document is not sent by the peer.
Content_Length represents the length of the document to be retrieved.
Content_Type represents the MIME type of the document to be retrieved.
Content_Encoding represents the additional content coding that has been applied to the document to be retrieved.

ITEM.P.SILENT: Thre are some features within OutPrms record which can also be found within InPrms record (see ), having the same fields if provided by the user or default ones, otherwise.
ITEM.P: SOut is bound with a byte stream representing the retrieved document. If toStrm feature of the InPrms record is set false, or when the requested document has been moved to an other URL, or a HEAD HTTP request is invoked, then SOut will not be bound.
Time is an integer and will be bound with the time when the service completes or fails. It is represented in secons since 00:00:00 GMT, Jan. 1, 1970.
Status is a string and represents the HTTP status code given by the peer (i.e. "200" for OK or "301" for Moved Permanently).
SizeRead is an integer which will be bound with the length of the document actually read.

SECTION.P:
Service is the base class for all the other classes present within this module. The reason we present it, is to describe the methods inhereted by the classes which specialise it.
bytesReadbytesRead(N)
Returns the number N of bytes read of the document being tranfered. closeAllcloseAll(Trace)
This method is used when, before the service completeness, its stop is required.
If Trace is bound to false, the current communication will be closed and the opened file removed. Else, if Trace is bound to true, the current communication and the opened file will be closed. It throws errCloseCon, errCloseFile or errRemFile exceptions (see ). fetchRatefetchRate(Rate)
Returns the current transmission rate Rate computed as the average of the last Smpl (see ) instanteous rates. initinit
Initialise the class.
serviceservice(Meth Url InPrms Pairs OutPrms HttpPrms)
Opens an HTTP communication session according to the given method Meth and fetches the document specified by the Url. Meth has to be one of the strings "GET" or "POST" for ordinary, gateway GET and gateway ISINDEX or gateway POST HTTP requests, respectively. Pairs has to be a list of "name=value" strings in the case of gateway GET and gateway POST, a "value" string in the case of gateway ISINDEX or unbound in the case of ordinary HTTP requests. All the other classes present in this module specialise this method.
As output, it returns two records containing both the content of the fetched document, namely OutPrms and the HTTP headers, namely HttpPrms. It throws all the exceptions described in (see ) but errRemFile.
For the explanation of all the other method's parameters refer to . startTempstartTemp
Continues the current communication session from the point stopTemp method temporarely stoped it. stopTempstopTemp
Temporarely stops the current communication session it. It can be continued by invoking the startTemp method.

CHAPTER.P: The examples given in this chapter are functors. As we've stated before, in , the main programming interface of the HttpClient package is provided by the specialised classes found within HttpClient module, namely CgiGET, CgiPOST, CgiISINDEX, UrlGET and UrlHEAD. In order to use them, we have to import 'HttpClient.ozf' module in our examples.

SECTION.P: This short example shows how a document located at Url can be downloaded using HttpClient.getUrl class. The first step is the initialisation of the class, using init method. Remark that the provided input parameters are unbound. In this case they will be given default values. The second step is calling the getService method, thus invoking the service. We don't want to reach the output parameters so we unbound them.
The content of the donloaded document will be put into the file having the given Url based name, "index.html" in our case.
HttpClient.getHEAD class can be used in the same manner. In this case the content of the document will not be fetched, but its HTTP headers will be returned.

This example shows how HttpClient.cgiGET class can be used to build CGI queries (i.e. to Yahoo web search engine). The query is given by CgiParams which is a list of "name=value" strings. In our very case, we want to retrieve a list of all documents related with the keyword "travel". Since the name of the file the retrieved document should be put is provided, it will be used.

The size of bytes of the requested document OutPrms.sizeRead read from the socket is displayed. Since it is a string, the name of the peer HttpPrms.server is displayed as an atom, so we can easily see it.
HttpClient.cgiPOST and HttpClient.cgiISINDEX classes can be used in the same manner. In the latter case CgiParams has to be a string.

Among the examples presented in this chapter, this one is the most complex and involves the use of the fetchRate, bytesRead, stopTemp and startTemp methods. It will display the transmission rate each 300 ms and the number of bytes of the document read at that time, by calling GetRate procedure.
After a period of 850 ms the transmission will be temporarely stoped and continued after other 3000 ms period.

Since toStrm feature is set true and toFile one is true by default, the document will be both saved into the provided name "temp" file, and returned as a byte stream to be processed by the ProcessStrm procedure.

This small example shows how two services can be started in parallel in order to download the same document having different locations Url1 and Url2. This will try to fetch the documents while each service runs within its own thread. When one of the services completes or fails, the application exits.

CHAPTER.P: In we described some useful examples of how to use HttpClient package. In this chapter we'll present some concrete applications which use this package.

SECTION.P: In this section we present a simple application whose main goal is to provide a graphical user interface of HttpClient package. The flexibility of the package's interface is reflected within the main frame's menu. For example, the package's classes are accessible within Services menu, and their optional parameters can me set by using Options menu.

As one can see in , the fetched document is not interpreted but displayed as it is. Thus, in the case of compressed files (i.e *.gz, *.zip), only displayable characters will be displayed by the Tcl/Tk text widget.
The GUI of the Web browser
For development of this application, Mozart Compiler 1.1.0 (20000111) playing Oz 3 was used. However, it works fine with 1.1.0 (19991213) version, too.
The web browser (source in bwoz.oz) can be compiled as follows: ozc -x bwoz.oz
and simply invoked as follows: bwoz

This application was inspired from the paper "Service Combinators for Web Computing" written by Luca Cardelli and Rowan Davies. It has as a starting point the questions related with the possibility of developing a script algorithm which should implement the actions a user, sitting in front of (say) a browser, could perform. These actions can be modeled with the use of special desined web based service combinators and basic services for invoking an HTTP server.

The application is being developed by Hadim Mustapha and consists of two main packages. The first one, deals with the user (programmer) interactions, the service combinators formating and certain decisions regarding the status of these services. The latter one is HttpClient package.
It will be available in the near future ...
